There are many flaws with this game, still I quite enjoyed it (at a discount purchase). - There are way too many collectibles (nearing 200). You need to collect a random number of things to unlock a story (e.g. 14 chainsaws). That's way too many and after collecting the necessary collectibles in the first section of the game I never did it again. - Sometimes you need to collect clues and the prompt for them are very precise. You need to angle the camera in just the right way which is very annoying for a game that's focused on that. - You need to battle demons in this game. It's by far the worst part which consists of teleporting between safe spots and trying to sneak up behind them. When I had the opportunity, I just ran by them to enter the next section. - It can be hard to find your way. This is partially because you can just walk through walls which is disorientating. At a later point in the game you learn to teleport which makes it even worse. - There are stealth section in this way where you need to guide your human partner while distracting guards by ringing the phone and other poltergeisty stuff. I didn't mind this is as much since it's easy and you don't seem to be able to fail (which I consider a good thing). - You sometimes posses a cat and run through vents because... you're in Salem? - There are (near) instant death traps and you die so incredibly fast, it's kindof funny? They just consist of black spots on the ground and are easily avoidable.  I enjoyed this game the best when I ignored the side stuff and just focused on the main case where you're trying to solve your own murder. I bypassed the demon battle sections as best I could. The cat scenes were ok but unnecessary. The stealth sections where you guide your partner was kindof fun. The main meat was the investigation stuff where you collect clues and try to figure out what precisely happened at the crime scene. I completed this game in 5 hours which is probably not worth it at full price but it was for me and I found that the story didn't drag.  Go buy it in a sale!

Ronan is a criminal-turned-cop who is killed by the mysterious Bell Killer. Playing as Ronan's ghost, investigate a series of crime scenes (sometimes with the help of teenage medium Joy), searching for identity of the killer. Many supernatural elements come into play – ghosts, witches, demons – and some flashbacks of the witch trials are pretty gruesome (drowning, burning, hanging).   As the investigation progresses, you'll explore a graveyard, an apartment house, an old mansion, a police station and of course the obligatory asylum level. While the game world is small, it is open, with the ability to just wander around the town of Salem. It's a gloomy place – the game occurs entirely at night – but is well-dotted with NPCs and collectibles. Obtaining collectibles can unlock other stories (usually brief, narrated cut-scenes), and some NPCs will provide side-missions. There's a decent amount of stuff to do, but most collectibles were easily found as I explored the town or a level.   Investigations require exploring a a crime scene, finding evidence (“Press E to analyze”) and sorting through the collected evidence (“Press Q to conclude the investigation”). Walking (or later, teleporting) around as a ghost feels fun; Ronan can walk through walls, possess people (mind-reading), and turn on random stuff to mess with the townsfolk (poltergeisting). Especially cool were the impenetrable “ghost walls” from past times that can block Ronan from exploring – or even provide new hazards (watch out for the ghost train!). Oh, and you can possess cats, too. This is actually crucial to progress through several stages of the game.  The demon sections, though, dragged the experience down a bit. Demons will sometimes spawn after completing an investigation. Their existence does have a crucial part to play, and they're easy enough to defeat with a little patience. Given that this is a supernatural tale, it would be rather weird if demons of some kind weren't in the game, and having some stealth sections added some variety to the gameplay. But after a while the demons became annoying distractions from the story.  And the narrative is where Murdered: Soul Suspect stands strongest. There is a lot of backstory to be found about Ronan and his wife (via collectibles). Sometimes collectibles are merely annoying, but they are worth pursuing here. Jason Brooks (as Ronan) and Cassidy Lehrman (as the medium, Joy) provide stand-out vocal performances. The graphics (Unreal 3) are great – murky and dark. Jason Graves' score provides a classic horror-story undertone. Murdered: Soul Suspect is a well-crafted detective game with a few quirks that holds its story aloft as its best attribute. If that sounds good to you, then go ahead and get this one.

Despite having its flaws,  Murdered: Soul Suspect  is quite possibly one of the most enjoyable single-player games I've played this year.  The Pros: · A unique story that feels like a combination of Silent Hill and L.A. Noire, and the beginning does a great job of introducing you to its atmosphere.  · You start at the point where Ronan O'Connor (the game's protagonist, of course) starts the hunt on his murderer, the Bell Killer. This makes you feel like you know as much about the afterlife as Ronan himself does and creates a sort of connection, right from the get-go. · The town of Salem is pretty small, but its yours to explore... and it's worth exploring. Tons of side missions and collectibles can be found in Salem, and the eerie mood that constantly lingers around really immerses you into Ronan's role. · The atmosphere is incredibly unique and satisfying. The ghostly white glow around certain object make the bridge-world connect with the world of the living. Seeing the flickering souls of dead children sitting next to a swing or a dead corpse dangling from a tree by its neck is oddly disturbing and makes you feel uncomfortable, which a bridge-world should. · Pretty cool characters. Ronan is your typical rebel-turned-cop tough guy, but his tattoo's reflect his life and the sins in it, and the detail to him is quite impressive. Even though he's partially see-through (because you know, he's a ghost and stuff), the orange bullet holes give Ronan a distinctive look from the other ghosts in Salem.  The Cons: · The mechanics feel a bit underused at times. As a ghost you could be able to do so much more, like possessing and controlling others for example. Sure, you can influence people and read their minds and control a cat (10/10), but it limits the player. · For a detective game, it doesn't really require too much thinking. You have to find clues and connect the dots (sometimes those dots connect in an unlogical way), and that's basically it. · The NPCs are mostly the same. Salem doesn't have many people walking its streets, but two of the same people might be sitting a few feet from each other. Plus, they have the same thoughts, which is weird. Like freaky weird. · The combat is there, but its simplistic and repetetive. You hide in lost souls, sneak up to a demon and quickly rip him apart. It's satisfying and it even feels as if you're helping those tormented souls, but it's just too much of the same.  The Visuals: · Most of its atmosphere comes from the visuals. Ghostly white silhouettes and detailed environments may not look next-gen, but they're stunning none the less.  Final Verdict: ·  Murdered: Soul Suspect  sure has its flaws, but it's a unique and highly enjoyable experience and easily one of my favorites of the year. 8/10

Murdered is a detective game with unique gameplay ideas such as the ability to walk through most objects. It's set in Salem, which is the American city known for its brutal witch trials, and this historical aspect is fully incorporated into the game.  The script writer clearly has done a great job because the game has you hooked until the very end, making you want to figure out what's to happen. The main characters are explored in depth throughout the game, with their stories and relationships being interesting and relatable, which can easily allow you to establish an emotional connection to them and even make you tear up. The good voice acting definitely contributes to that as well.  There are some genuine horror elements to this game, although it's mostly about exploration in the dark, noir, relatively small but detailed world with a lot of paranormal elements.

For those, like me, who enjoy problem solving games, this was great. It wasn't an intense action game, but simple observation which I enjoyed. Over the course of the game, you can uncover ghost stories as well that aren't even critical to the gameplay, just bonuses. That little mechanic made it feel more immersive considering the story wasn't riding on backtracking or extra digging. Something that stood out for me in the way of dialoge was that everyone who speaks doesn't necessarily talk one at a time. Characters will get cut off and complete their thoughts later in a way that doesn't sound like a script nor rehearsed, with exception to the protagonist's classic-detective style inner monolouges. However, the quick-time controls felt awkward, the game was too short (beat it within twelve hours with a majority of the achievements done), and many 'clues' didn't seem to make sense when trying to piece crimescenes together.  The promise of unique abilities ('personal strengths becoming abilities) was limited to maybe one or two involving revealing information (which felt closer to the protagonist's job rather than his actual strengths). Even only one other ghost displayed only one unique ability that didn't seem to connect to their character. All of the other abilities you gain belong to the other ghosts you find as well, making the protagonist (and the other ghost with a unique ability) possess very cookie-cutter characteristics. Very little direction is taken towards obstacles you run into like the demons, spiteful cops, or paranoia plaguing the area, thus leaving much more to be desired in character development. 'Extra' characters aren't even kept within the game for very long, making it feel as though there are only four real characters, and many filler characters. I 'did' enjoy the game and do recommend it for those who enjoy dark, investigative, or easy-paced games. Sadly this has little to no replayability and would wait for it to go on sale for $15 or under given it's short story and neglect to several details I mentioned earlier.

Let's get one thing out of the way: 'Murdered: Soul Suspect' is not your normal action game. Actually, it is actually not an action game at all; it is more a story-driven adventure focused on exploration and (very logic) puzzle-solving that centers around clue finding and logic implications among them; the plot is thick, with lots of twists and turns all along the way which will nail you to your chair until you're done. There's only one caveat: it's rather short -- I managed to complete it in under 10 hours. There are also 'combat' sequences against demons (ghosts that turned evil after forsaking what they were meant to 'fix' in the living world before leaving it) that are more annoying than anything else as they involve hide-and-seek mechanics; I think that there is a lot of room for improvement in that area but I am not complaining too much. There is one more thing that I dislike though: the whole collectable item craze that the game is so soaked with. Some are in obvious places, others in less-obvious ones, while others are really unfindable unless you comb the town of Salem systematically -- and it's rather hard to do it without a map of the place. Through the collection of clues and items, you either go forward with the main story or unlock sidequests or insights about the protagonists and the town itself.  When it comes to presentation, graphics are really good (locked at 30 FPS but there's no sensation of lag at all), the audio acting is well done and the music hits the spot without being particularly memorable.  I recommend this game if you're into ghost stories (or well-written stories in general) and like to enjoy a slower-paced game that requires a minimum of thinking.  My vote for the game: 7/10 (with a gameplay vote of 5.5/10 and one for the story of 8.5/10)

I have very mixed feelings about this game. Over all I'd recommend it. Here are my thoughts:  Positives:  The story was absolutely awesome. The whole concept of solving your own death on its own was great, but then the actual mystery behind your murder is rather compelling. I played this with my girlfriend watching and she was never ready for me to stop for the night. So I'd recommend the game just for the story alone!  Throughout the game, there are collectable items that give some insight into the history of Salem and the Witch Trials as well as random little stories about certain events relevant to the area being explored. These add a cool dimension to the game taking away from the story and adding some cool information.  Playing as a ghost and getting to use ghost abilities was pretty sweet.  Negatives:  The BIGGEST flaw in my opinion is the use of demons in this game. I think the game is good enough on its own to just be a mystery without the demons in there to give a 'horror' feel. Truthfully, the demons didn't seem to serve a real purpose to the game and were only in a few spots to take up your time and add just a bit of difficulty to the game. In such a story-driven game, I think leaving this out would have made the game even better because you wouldn't have to go through buildings wondering if a demon is going to pop out or not; you could have just gone on wondering about the story and exploring every facet of the city.  Another big flaw, as I've read in several other reviews and agree with, is that you get really awesome ghost abilities, position, for example. When possessing a person, you can do several things. However, you can really only do something cool or useful with possession on major characters; on background characters, you can only mindread and for a vast majority of these characters, their thoughts are recycled (so you get the same thought from several characters throughout the city).  Overall, I'd absolutely recommend this game. While there were a couple things that bothered me, the story really was enjoyable. Honestly, this could even make a movie. Definitely worth a play-through.

I picked up Murdered: Soul Suspect because a good friend kept stressing how good it is (in spite of all the negative reviews), and I wasn't at all disappointed with the game. In fact, I enjoyed it a lot more than I ever thought I would! The game relies largely on its characters and the murder mystery that's central to said characters' lives. If you're looking for a fast-paced, highly action-driven game, it doesn't deliver on that front - but that's what made it such a great ride for me as a player.  I wasn't sure what to expect of the game from the premise alone, but it does atmospheric horror really well, along with the splashes of detective fiction and noir, too. Investigating, gathering clues, questioning witnesses, and making deducions are all important to the game. It even has an historical angle that I first thought would be somewhat canned, but actually surprised me a bit by the end.  Collecting is an important part of the game and, although it's 'optional,' a lot of the story content depends on how well you can scour a map for all of the items - some hidden and some not. Even with ~10 hours play time into my first 'completed' game, I still didn't track everything down! So if you're a completionist who enjoys searching and interacting with maps, M:SS definitely appeals on that front.  The other main challenge of the game is demon encounters, and they can be tricky to master at first, since some of the combinations are a little awkward. Still, by the last few maps it seems easier (as the difficulty doesn't really go up much during the course of the game) ... but it's definitely anxiety-inducing sometimes! All in all, the demon encounters kept the game from feeling extremely linear (i.e., like a visual novel).  So if you're into mysteries and crime fiction, love spooky stuff, and enjoy a game that burns a little slowly, definitely give it a try.

Murdered: Soul Suspect - Spoiler Free Review  First off, I'd like to point out that I like both pulp noir and ghost stories both of which are heavy influences on the general feel of this game. If you do not like either the cinematography stylings of pulp noir (in which case, you won't like the cut-scenes and may dislike the characters on occassion) or think ghost stories are dull, then this is not the game for you.   For those of you still with me and looking at potentially buying this game a bit of background is in order. The studio that released M:SS closed down despite really ploughing everything into this game. Part of it is odd in places, which I'll get to, but mostly they'd been struggling for a while due to releasing a couple of games which were bombs a while back. Any future updates to the game will have to be community driven but that at least is one piece of good news - after multiple playthroughs I only came across one minor glitch, once, and it was a graphical one that I couldn't replicate. The game runs really well so future patching should not be necessary.  So, where to start? How about the story. It's pretty standard fair, almost straight out of a 'Randall & Hopkirk: Deceased' episode. You're a detective in Salem when a call is put in about a strange hooded man breaking into an apartment building. As you are an emotional loose cannon after your wifes' death (it's actually nice to play a character who's irrational behaviour gets some explanation for once) you chase after him alone only to find that he's too strong for you, the eventual fight resulting in your death. Your purpose is to stop the killer from beyond the grave so that your spirit can move on and be reunited with your wife.   This opening is actually really impressive as it's almost entirely done using the in-game engine and graphically looks superb, the sweeping camera shots and the slow-motion work really well giving a strong movie quality feel but rather than just have you as a passenger watching the opening the developer makes you take part in it, trying to first catch the killer and even trying to survive the attack. The sound is excellent too and is nicely understated, something that carries throughout the whole game.  After this you're left, dead, in Salem trying to figure out how you can stop this killer. There's a tutorial which covers the controls and then you're given objectives to complete but you are left to wander through reasonably large parts of Salem without being stopped. As you're dead you come across other spirits and left over memories of Salem in it's past, which just helps to make the world more interesting and full and the contrast in design is really well realised, especially when it ties in with the sidequests and main stories. The more you progress the more of Salem opens up to you, allowing you to find out more about Salems past and revisit areas you have already explored. The team have been as historically accurate as possible, considering that the game is a work of fiction, and you'll get to pick up on a real flavour of Salems darker past as you wander town.  Character design suits the mood of the town too and there are characters in period dress in certain areas, although they are very few and far between, I'd have liked to have seen more of them. They are reasonably realistic to look at - not ultra-real - which would feel out of place in a ghost story, but real anyway with very good motion capture and facial expressions especially on the main ones. One that stood out to me is a point where a character manages to pretty much lie with just their face for a split second near the end, you'll know it when you see it, but the technology is well utilised without being overdone, it does not take you out of the story or gameplay very much if ever.  As a ghost you get to travel through walls but presumably due to hardware limitations this pretty much is only really used within enclosed spaces, though this is explained within the game-worlds mythos itself well enough and it can be quite good fun. These sections really can make you feel like a running, screaming spirit. I felt less like a spirit and more like I was going to have a seizure due to swoosh noise everytime you select a conversation topic. It's fine in short conversations but they can be long and a little grating if you want to find out everything.  There's some disturbing bits in this game too. Some pretty nasty deaths of young women, some ghosts have some surprisingly harrowing and well-acted lines, almost mini-stories, of their own if you come across them and there are collectables that unlock urban legends, a couple of which are genuinely quite creepy. There are places with a lot of extra details added in which build up a wonderful sense of dread and oppression too, a lot of which can easily be missed and overlooked as it is just there for scene-setting.   Controls are pretty tight, the camera is good but can be a bit awkward when you are possessing something or trying to get through a wall slowly. But there are two elephants in the room and these are what most reviewers scored the game so harshly on.  1) Pointless Sort-of Forced Combat/Stealth Sections.  You do combat, you either have to go for it whole-heartedly or just don't do it. In for a penny, in for a pound! M:SS feels like it's dipping it's fingers into the collection bowl and wondering if it can get away with giving a two Christmas old chocolate coin. You get an enforced stealth section, taking you out of the more interesting portion of the game which feels jarring, so you can try to sneak past these demon-monsters which look like the Nozghul if they'd been drinking sheep-dip. It hardly ever works so you have to try to stealth kill them, which is only a temporary fix.   2) Escort Mission  The escort is at least useful but these are really badly designed - it barely matters if you get spotted because the spotter sub-routine is so badly programmed.  Both of these things feel tacked on and out of place. I have a sneaking suspicion that they received orders from their publisher that if they wanted a Triple A advertising budget then it had to have those things in it because they feel completely at odds with the rest of the game. And yes, I will be doing a video rant I am that annoyed about it.  Mercifully, there's only a handful of those sections and apart from that and one point with a truly stupid portrayal of mental illness (completely different to an earlier scene with a ghost in a bath), the rest of the game is pretty much excellent. If you can stick out those few parts you will find a good to look at, engaging murder mystery, with an excellent twist and interesting backdrop and characters.  I recommend it, but have to dock it marks for 1) & 2)   Total Score: 7.5/10   Well above average and definitely worth a play if you want a murder mystery that's a little different or a slowly paced adventure game.

8/10 This is a very mediocre “game.” Let me explain that. If that were all there was to this, then I would obviously have given it a thumbs down. As a game, it’s just so-so, but as a piece of entertainment, it is fantastic. The actual gameplay has its ups and downs. There are really only a very few elements to the whole experience. You have exploration (walking around large/medium sized areas.) Collection (there are little glowing things liberally sprinkled around everywhere to pick up, and they all have some interesting tidbit to share.) There are a few stealth sequences, and then there are mysteries to solve. As for exploring, and collecting; I love and hate this sort of thing in games. A lot of games have them these days, and I have an unhealthy compulsion to collect all/most that I can. It’s not even for the achievements. I just have to. It’s like wringing out every bit of value that I can from a game. There are objects to be found, and I must find them. The stealth, is pretty horrible. This actually drags the gameplay as a whole from being good-ish down to mediocre. Plainly put, the stealth sections hurt this game greatly. For people who don’t play games, and would like to experience the story, these sections are going to be too difficult and very frustrating. For people who DO play games, these sections are just going to be annoying. They aren’t very difficult for a gamer, they just become tedious. Luckily they aren’t in there too often. Just, once in a while, when you are on your way to something interesting – boom. Ohh noos. Demons. I suppose I will have to watch them float around their 3 different way-points until it’s facing the way it’s obviously designed for me to kill it. Then, there are the mysteries. These are pretty fun. They are not unlike Phoenix Wright. There is a smallish area. and within that area are clues strewn about. Once you find all (or most) you can solve the mystery by selecting the correct “clue(s)” to answer whatever question the game is asking. Unfortunately this sometimes causes problems because the clues that they are asking for sometimes don’t make sense. The mystery asks for what seems like a specific answer, but instead accepts answers that are just vague repetitions of themselves. You’ll find yourself annoyed at the end of some of these sections when you find out which answers the game actually wanted you to pick. You’ll be able to think, “I guess that kind of makes sense?” but also roll your eyes because it doesn’t directly, and you are penalized for selecting incorrectly. Luckily the penalty isn’t too harsh, and you have unlimited retries. The only punishment is that you might get less “badge points” for how well you do. As far as I could tell, these points literally never had any bearing on anything. That is all of the gameplay that there is to this game. So as a game, it doesn’t do very well. However, most everything else about it is great. Great story, interesting characters, interesting setting. Great music, great voice acting (mostly), pretty decent graphics. The ending was a little bit abrupt, but there’s a little twist you might not quite see coming. Luckily for this game, to me, the gameplay didn’t matter too much. I kept coming back to find out what was going to happen next, and to see what little mysteries I could uncover in and around the spooky city of Salem. I ended up having a really good time with Murdered: Soul Suspect, and if they were to make a sequel, I would most definitely give it a purchase.

Murdered: Soul Suspect is an excellent game. I don't usually write reviews, but I wanted to address the few issues that people do have with the game  The usual subject of criticism in Murdered: Soul Suspect is the combat system. The fact is, however, that Murdered is not a combat-based game. If all you care about is fighting, this wasn't gonna be the game for you to begin with. The combat system isn't like most fighting games, but that's because it's not designed to be. Murdered isn't an action game - Murdered is about telling a story.  This brings up the other common complaint about Murdered: that the story is too short. Sure, you can beat the game in six hours, but, the fact is, you shouldn't. Murdered is also a game about exploration. As an example, each story mission gives evidence you'll need but also some you won't. This makes sense, as when you're looking around a crime scene, not everything you notice is going to be relevant. In the end, you have to choose what pieces of evidence are relevant to what you want to know. So sure, you could just find the necessary pieces of evidence and realize 'Hey, I can solve this now.' Alternatively, you could try to find all the evidence anyways. There are also hidden collectibles that explain some of the backstory but are not necessary to progress in the game. Side missions don't present the player with any rewards, but do provide short interactions with other ghosts (not to say that these side missions are perfect though). The atmosphere of the town of Salem is captivating and makes it fun to just walk around and explore. As a ghost, you can possess any human and read their thoughts. Granted, the thoughts of random civilians in the streets can get repetitive and reused, but in story missions these thoughts are more unique. So if you're the kind of person who likes to rush through the game, your experience will be short, but that's because it won't be the full experience. My personal playstyle was to seek out all the collectibles that I could (but not obsess over getting all of them), explore the town of Salem as well as the locations for the story missions (the police station and museum are particularly neat), read everyone's thoughts (at least in story missions), look for all the evidence I could find, and read anything I could find lying around. I'm not saying that everyone should play this way or that my way is the only way/correct way to play, but I do feel like gamers who like exploration will get much more out of this than players who don't due to the atmospheric nature of the game. In doing such, not only did it make it a more enjoyable experience for me, but it also lengthened the completion time a little bit  Anyways, pros/cons: + Graphics + Story/Atmosphere/Characters/Lore + Voice Acting + Unique ghost gameplay - Side missions leave a little something to be desired - Certain collectibles can only be collected during certain story missions, so if you miss them then they're gone  In short, Murdered: Soul Suspect is a great game, but make sure you know what to expect before getting it. Many of the bad reviews are from people who expected it to be an action game, when in truth it never presented itself as such. Murdered is more of a linear interactive movie. If you like story-driven games, this is the game for you, but if gameplay is all you care about then save your money.

Murdered: Soul Suspect takes a fascinating part of American history and pairs it with a supernatural detective story. The environment and plot is very creative and unique and kept me interested until the end. The game is fairly short and doesn't overstay its welcome, yet still provides a lot of character and plot development as well as a few twists.   That being said, there are two minor downfalls to this game.   The first is the overuse of collectibles. While the collectibles are easy enough to find and doesn't require too much 'post game time' to sit down and sniff them out, there are still a ton of them. Over 170 in fact. Each collectible gives some sort of backstory to the world or relevent major characters, but the sheer number of them will have you running to pick them up first before doing the actual story missions. I feel this can really take the player out of the setting and mood Murdered: Soul Suspect tried to create, with its old, colonial, haunted theme. If you are the type of player to skip right over collectibles and not be bothered, then this isn't a problem for you. But if you are OCD, have to get them all, hear every backstory, learn every secret, then this will probably get on your nerves a bit.  The other issue to this game is that some of the puzzles are unclear as to how you should go about solving them. While this has only happened to me about maybe 15% of the puzzles in the game, it is still frustrating to look up the answer and say to yourself 'How does that make sense?'. The game does give hints if you get the puzzle wrong, but sometimes the hints aren't that clear. With some trial and error, you should be ok though.  Overall, I enjoyed this game. I picked it up when it was $4 and would have gladly paid $20 for it. The setting and plot were really unique and I liked all of the ghost mechanics that were added into the game. It is definitely a game to play when you are looking to get a good story with some amusing puzzles. I rate this game a 9/10.

Save your money.  I was pretty excited to play this game, but after completing the main story-line in under 9 hours I am severely disapointed.   Difficulty:  This game is incredibly easy. It's basically point-and-click. You can't make any mistakes, really. You walk between locations and look for clues, which are very obviously highlighted for you. I thought I'd have to be solving puzzles, piecing together clues, but everything is spoon-fed to you. The main character must be the worst detective in history, because I was figuring things out way before he was. There's no real threat or doom in this game. I mean, you're already dead, so you can't exactly die. The only obstacle (if you can call it that) are the soul-sucking demons (Which look like Dementors from Harry Potter) which pop up and must be vanquished (Which is also very easy to do. Just sneak up behind them, click three buttons and POOF! Gone).  Story:  The story could be interesting if it wasn't painfully dummed down. There are no complex intertwining stories, no in-depth characters. Everyone is exceptionally bland and cliche. *Spoilers ahead* So you play a detective called Ronan in Salem who has just been murdered by the 'Bell Killer'. Ronan is exceptionally slow. It takes most of the game for him to figure out that this 'Bell Killer' preys on 'witches'. (It's Salem. That was obvious.) He discovers who the murderer is with the help of a 'Medium' who can see/communicate with the dead.   Graphics: Even the graphics themselves aren't that good. The characters mouths move at random, not really forming any real words. They move their arms and heads around as if they're puppets being pulled by strings. Even the cinematics are poor; clothes have jagged edges, and character's faces have no emotion.  Glitches:  There are glitches in this game which don't allow you to complete current objectives. Also, it's a checkpoint save game, so if you encounter a glitch you must reload from the last save-point (wherever thay may be). I also had a problem of cinematic scenes repeating themselves if I walked into a location where the objectives had already been completed.   World: There is a very small area of game play. No map needed. You are in a tiny town and you are able to enter the museum, the church, the graveyard, the police station and the hospital (but only when the game calls for it). No free-roaming or exploring. Just walk to the next location (the arrows show you the way) and complete the objective. Then it's on to the next location.   Overall:  This is a VERY boring, VERY easy game. Utterly dissapointing.   Rating: 2/10

The type of game that makes me wish for a recommendation of 'Only on sale' One of the few games out there that lets you play as a ghost doing actual ghost like things, the game is marred by several issues that really prevent it from working enough for me to give it a pass at normal prices. It's a puzzle game first and foremost that felt it had to add in some action in the form of stealth segments where you must avoid getting caught by demons, which usually boils down to accidentally getting spotted and having to waste time teleporting around safe spots waiting for them to resume patrolling so you can try again at doing a QTE to get them out of an area so you can go back to exploring. And then there's the puzzles, that boil down to trying to find every object in a given area and putting 2 or 3 of them together to solve a small mystery, sometimes operating off of logic and other times suffering from the Phoenix Wright problem where you're ahead of the game's characters but are forced to answer extremely handholding questions in order to advance (such as 'there was a murder' as one of an early mystery's 'most relevant' clues when you are asked to investigate a murder). However, that's not what really hurts this game. Instead, it's the simple lack of content. There isn't enough dialogue recorded for a game that features a mind-reading mechanic. There are very few side quests and after you complete them all the hub world you are forced to travel through seems very boring. Collectables are decent but don't seem to ever really be enough considering the amount of ground you cover between them. The main plot ends way too early for something that came out above $20. And those demons mentioned above? They are thrown in purely to prevent you from breezing through levels in 10 minutes. As you'll probably get through most of the content you care about in the first run, the game really lacks a lot of replay value, so your first run through is going to be about as long as you spend with the game. I went through with the 'I'm going to try to collect as much as I can, but more than an hour without any result and I'm moving on' mentality, and I clocked about 8 hours (which includes a bit of idling time spent away from the computer).  It's kind of sad, because the game isn't devoid of value, just not enough to justify purchasing it normally. Its writing, especially concerning some of the ghost stories you come across, is engaging, even if it's not the best you'll ever experience. Meanwhile, it completely nails the 'I'm playing as a ghost detective' thing it was going for, even going so far as to have the first thing you do be trying to get back into your still barely alive body by trying to slip into it. If you liked Ghost Trick or Geist and wanted more games like that, this scratches that itch nicely.  This game is worth playing for those who have a weakness for a somewhat noir detective game or one where you play as a ghost, but because you'll probably only need to play it once, get it on sale.

I stopped bothering after a while, and I'm usually a completionist. * Repetitive dialogue from people you possess so why bother? * Many clues are unnecessary or illogical and thus a waste of time * The writing is dull at best and sometimes ridiculous * Riddled with cliches/nothing really original * Uninspired level and NPC design * No real rewards or motivation other than to unmask the killer. I can see how some people might recommend this game. There is stuff to like about it, it's playable, but as a big studio title I'm going to take the harsher route and not recommend it. Mostly because it's so underwhelming, gameplay and story wise.  The game play is super casual. Reduntantly casual. Most of the game focuses around collecting clues, but you don't derive any meaning from them. Once you've found the right clues you can opt to solve the case and the game will ask you a straight forward question like 'what happened here', or 'where did the killer go next' and you click on the clues that blatantly answer the question. There's no deduction involve, just fill in the blank and then the character will summerize the obvious as though they were hit with some hard earned revelation.  There is also the hunt/be hunted aspect of the game. Every area has one or two sections where demons emerge and you either have to navigate through them, or destroy them without them attacking you. It was kind of like the developer was trying to include some action in the game, but it was pretty pointless. They didn't really get any more difficult as the game progressed and they had nothing to do with the story. It made me wonder if the developers were playing with what kind of genre they wanted the game to be and ended up not developing or cutting out any of the possibilities. Heck, even the opening scene of us trying to get back into our body uses a gimicky game play element that we don't see again for the rest of the game. It obviously wasn't an interesting enough element to use again, why is it still in there?  The story is also pretty mediocre. I guess it's fine, it wasn't painful, it was just blah. The superficial questions were answered, but there wasn't really any explaination as to why any of it was happening, nor was there any real character development for anyone. The story did conclude, which is more satisfying than some games, but there wasn't really much reward for exploring so much game territory. In fact, there were lots of smaller unrelated stories that presented themselves in the first half of the game that were probably more interesting and involving than the main plot. I think they got tired of programming ghosts in the second half of the game or something because the NPCs that drove these side stories stopped asking for help, and suddenly all the NPCs that had about 2 lines of original monologue each started sharing about 4 lines between all of them.  All in all, I'm sure some people will like this game. Maybe many will find it on the positive side of mundane, but personally I found it to be an overglorified, padded, hidden object game. It could really use some editing, and it would be a nice bonus if they actually decided on an aspect of the game to develop into something interesting.

But I'll get back to that.  Wanna walk through that wall there? You can't. Why? Cause if you did, you would bypass that demon thats spesifically placed in your corridor path. They don't feel like they should be there. They are only there to slow you down, make you focus on them instead of whats around you. So that, you know, you miss out on that clue? Cheap trick. And annoyed me to no end. They are easy to take out, but it still messes up the flow of the game.  When i finished my initial 'tutorial'-chapter, I was exited that I finally could roam the streets of the city. What happened instead was deep and utter dissapointment. Just looking at the city I knew exactly what was going to happen in the future.   Demons are going to chase me here. I'm going to be forced to hide here and here, then I'll probably have to run up there ... cut-scene i guess, then run again over there. Oh, this path is blocked. Yeah, that will probably open up later when I've waved my magical wand. That guy doesnt want to talk to me, but in his conversation his rubbing it in my face 'im not gonna talk to you'. Translation? I'll talk to you, but first you have to do something. And the streets are littered with 'clues' that tell you about the plot, killer and well everything.   Oh joy. Cause thats what I want to do. I want to learn about the murderer and why he does what he does by jumping and exploring the terrain instead of the story.  And the story. Why didn't they hire better writers? At least let us keep guessing the 'why' untill after some gameplay. When the gamer feel like you know the 'why' right after chapter 1 - then you seriously have done something really really wrong. Thats not storytelling - thats insisting that the gamer is an idiot. And lazy.  It was just such a let down, I never finished chapter 2. Or was it 3? I dont know, and i dont care.

Let me save you the time, and let you know that while this will be a review, it is going to read as more of a rant than anything else. Understand going in that I am not going to recommend any one play this game, at all. The reasons will be detailed below, but I am writing this as a way of venting my frustrations with the game, and treating the main purpose of this as a 'buyers beware' because let me tell you, I am not going to let the store page lie to you. I will get to that in a second.   That being said, Murdered Soul Suspect is the most dissapointing game of the year for me. Hands down. When it comes to expectations (what little I had asked from it in the first place) Not only did they fail miserably, they somehow managed to fail at even the BASIC expectations. So what were my expectations? I just wanted a good mystery game. Interact with the environment/clues, piece stuff together. Learn about the mystery and basically just immerse myself as a detective. It didn't have to be a compelling narrative or anything, but for the story, I at LEAST wanted a likable main character. I didn't EXPECT an L.A. Noire esque mystery game, and I would have even allowed a Deadly Premonition esque kind of mystery game. But this......WHAT IS THIS?  Where do I even begin with this game. I hope if you are foolish enough to read my tirade you will at least have the respect for yourself to have a snack. Buckle in boys and girls, here comes the salt. I want to address the store page bullet points real quick. To get this out of the way now. It's a good starting point as any. I won't address them all, just the ones I object to, and you, the future buyer, deserve to know the truth of.   -'A twisting storyline supported by a great cast of characters constantly raises questions over the secrets that Salem hides.' This is cute. What great cast of characters? No. I am not being facetious, I mean what great cast of characters? Where are they? There are characters, sure, and I would have loved to learn more about them, but 75% of the cast occassionally drops in for that ol 'THEY COULD BE THE KILLER' scooby doo schtick. No in reality the game really only focuses on Ronan (main character) and Joy, his spirit medium. Every other character isn't any more developed than the last beyond fulfilling the cliche role they were intended to fulfill. There is no 'constantly raising questions over the secrets that Salem hides.' It's no secret. No, I want you as the reader, right now, to mentally say the first thing that comes to mind when you hear the word Salem. If you said 'oh the Salem witch trials right?' then you my friend, are one smart turkey. Tadah. Oh, and there is only one main twist. I don't know where this twisting storyline business comes from. That implies it's constantly twisting.  -' Move freely from one haunting location to the next and even if you have completed your investigation, return to previous scenes to follow new leads.' Sounds compelling right? By move freely they mean you are essentially in a little invisible walled off box, and boy let me tell you there are a TON of invisible walls. Yes, you can return to previous scenes, but 'to follow new leads?' What on EARTH are you TALKING ABOUT? The only time you return to a previous scene is if you forgot some disposable optional collectible you wanted to collect for 100% completion that doesn't do jack for you unless you are trying to get all the achievements. None of this 'new lead' bullcrap. You don't change the outcome of anything. You are merely just taking a guided tour through this game.  -'Seek-out hundreds of collectibles, side-quests and cases from Salem’s citizens past to learn facts about the town and its people, improve your detective ranking and help you piece together the truth about the killer.' If there was ever a burning point I wanted to address, it's this one. This one, singular sentence on their page. It's complete false advertising. First off, while there are a COUPLE hundred (not hundreds) of collectibles, there are NOT hundreds of sidequests and cases from Salem's citizens. There are FOUR cases (not a typo) where you help out deceased citizens, and EIGHT collectible sidequests that reveal a story of a previous murder not really tied to the main quest murders. The other collectibles that involve the main quest killer? They don't help you piece together ANYTHING about the killer other than he likes killing and little blurbs from tabloids. How does that HELP anything? and honestly, with how poorly fleshed out and planned the characters were, you can more or less figure out who the killer is within the first 2-3 hours of gameplay. The twist was nice, but again, you kind of expect it. The really sucky part about all this is they should have done more with the sidequests involving helping the citizens come to term with their death. But no, you get 4 quests, and the other spirits you run into, you get a two choice branch that changes nothing and it just falls flat. Or hey! hey! better yet! more of those collectible stories involving the side murders but you know, without the cheap copout collectible requirements! MAKE THOSE ACTUAL MISSIONS. It would have been a farcry better than what we actually received.  -'Survive powerful demonic spirits who devour souls in a belief that they can regain their own. Strategically use supernatural abilities to evade and outwit them before they tear away your soul forever.' HAHAHHAHA, 'strategically?' STRATEGICALLY?! Are you kidding me?! What STRATEGY? Wh-what, you mean, exploiting the terrible AI of the 3 enemies at any given moment by hiding in plain sight, waiting for them to lose aggro, then mashing a QTE prompt? Or, or, using the various distraction options available (j/king you can only distract them with one thing, a crow) and then rinsing and repeat? Get out of here with that nonsense. Stop dressing up this lazy nonsense to sound fancy. Shame on you.  Now that is out of the way, let's talk 'gameplay.' Well, you can basically consider this game a semi-rails game. Or, more or less, a guided tour game. You aren't actually playing the game. I mean, yes,you are controlling Ronan, and he is responding to your controls, but literally 60% of the gameplay is you collecting stuff. It's like a giant collectible scavenger hunt. When you aren't collecting things that have no rhyme or reason or impact to the game, the other 40% of the game is you 'solving' crime scenes. But, YOU aren't solving SQUAT. The GAME has that covered. Look, there is no penalty for guessing wrong or deducing something wrong. All the clues are in the same room. There is no interacting with clues. Hell, the game will sometimes literally zoom in on the primary clue in a cutscene before you even start, rendering all your clue collecting pointless. AND, when you DO have all the clues collected, guess what reader? The game is like, 'soooo what do you think happened' and you piece together 1-3 of the clues to 'solve the scene.' BUT AGAIN, there is no penalty for failing. It's as braindead as you can possibly get. My favorite moment occurs when the killer is looking at a picture, and the game asks me 'Well, what do you think he is doing?' and 6+ words flood the screen and you gotta figure out what he is doing. He is clearly startled and up to no good, and literally half the options are the exact opposite of the mood being displayed. What is this, Dora the Explorer?   Agh... this game, I haven't even scratched much of the surface, there is so much I want to talk about. So much...so much rage. But I have already spent too much time talking about the game. Look, I don't like it. I think it's highway robbery they would seriously ask for $50 of YOUR HARD EARNED MONEY for this crap.   TL;DR: I hate this game.
